title: Why rosé is not just a summer wine – and where to buy the best deep pinks to drink in winter
text:
There’s a new word in France for shimmeringly pale rosé: nacre – mother of pearl – denoting a wine so light in colour that you can barely tell whether it’s white or pink.

The craze for exceedingly pale rosé has swept across the world. It started in Provence, of course, but winemakers from Spain to California, indeed almost everywhere pink wine is made, have succumbed, turning wines that might once have been peony pink or the hue of raspberry juice into wispy followers of fashion.

Before we all became so obsessed with pale there was another kind of rosé. It’s still there, if you look hard enough, and the best place to start is Tavel, the appellation in the southern Rhône, next to Lirac and on...
